text:
Although the word FOLKLORE is more than a century old, no exact agreement has ever been reached as to its meaning. The common idea presented in all folklore is that of tradition, something handed down from one person to another and preserved either by memory or practice rather than the written record. It involves the dances, songs, tales, legends and traditions, the beliefs and superstitions, and the proverbial sayings of people everywhere. It also includes studies of traditional agricultural and domestic practices, types of buildings and utensils, and traditional aspects of social organizations.

— Smith Thompson, Mythology and Legend, Paul and Virginia, 1949

YOUR CO-OPERATION in answering this list of questions is greatly appreciated. By thus writing down what you know, you have contributed to the permanent record of our Province. All Questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives.

Directions for filling out the questionnaire:

1. Print all proper names and place names in capital letters.
2. Use ink if possible.
3. If space allowed is insufficient for your answer, use either the back of this sheet or a separate sheet of paper; put the number of the question at the beginning of this continuation.
4. If you are unable to answer a question, skip it. We realize that not everyone can answer every question.

A SPECIAL SUGGESTION: The answers in this questionnaire are a case of "one thing leads to another". It is therefore a good idea to fill it out in groups rather than individually. However, if grouping is not possible, individual answers are also desirable. Groups might be neighbors.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:
Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

CIRCULATED IN CO-OPERATION WITH THE SASKATCHEWAN GOLDEN JUBILEE COMMITTEE.
Although the word FOLKLORE is more than a century old, no exact agreement has ever been reached as to its meaning. The common idea presented in all folklore is that of tradition, something handed down from one person to another and preserved either by memory or practice rather than the written record. It involves the dances, songs, tales, legends and traditions, the ballets and superstitions, and the proverbial sayings of people everywhere. It also includes studies of traditional agricultural and domestic tasks, the weaving of buildings and utensils, and traditional aspects of social organizations.

Standard Dictionary of Folklore, Mythology and Legend, Funk and Wagnalls, 1949

YOUR CO-OPERATION in answering this list of questions is greatly appreciated. By thus writing down what you know, you have contributed to the permanent record of our Province. ALL Questionnaires are preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives.

Directions for filling out the questionnaire:

1. Print all proper names and place names in capital letters.
2. Use ink if possible.
3. If space allowed is insufficient for your answer, use either the back of the sheet or a separate sheet of paper; put the number of the question at the beginning of this continuation, skip it. We realize that not everyone can answer every question.
4. If you are unable to answer a question, skip it. We realize that not everyone can answer every question.

A SPECIAL SUGGESTION: The answers in this questionnaire are a case of "one thing leads to another." It is therefore a good idea to fill it out in groups rather than individually. (However, if grouping is not possible, individual answers are also desirable). Groups might be neighbors.

Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

CIRCULATED IN CO-OPERATION WITH THE SASKATCHEWAN GOLDEN JUBILEE COMMITTEE.

Address: EARL GREY

(Pioneer Address)

Where did your parents live before that? (From what year to what year?)

Age: 77

Where born: Weyburn, SASK.

Occupation by which you earn a living: Farmer

Hobbies or talents (either for pleasure or to supplement your income) such as: playing a musical instrument; hunting; trapping; collecting curiosities; photography, etc.

Father's occupation before coming to Saskatchewan:

After: Farmer

Father's hobbies or talents:

Mother's hobbies or talents, such as: fine sewing or other handwork; china or other paintings; playing a musical instrument, etc.

II SETTLEMENT

The Land

1. Where you lived or now are living, are there any natural features or landmarks (e.g., butte, coulee, valley, stream). Take? Name?

May be called?
I. INTRODUCTION

Address: EARL GREY

Where did your parents live before that? (From what year to what year?)

What language did your father (or you) speak before coming to Canada?

Age: 77
Where born: Norway
Occupation by which you earn a living: Farmer

Hobbies or talents (either for pleasure or to supplement your income) such as: playing a musical instrument; hunting; trapping; collecting curiosities; photography, etc.

Father's occupation before coming to Saskatchewan:

After: Farmer

Father's hobbies or talents:

II. SETTLEMENT

The Land

1. Where you lived or now are living, are there any natural features or landmarks (e.g., butte, coulee, valley, stream)? Take Name? Why so called? What stories are connected with them?
2. What jokes did people tell about (a) gumbo (b) foxing streams or getting caught in unusual situations caused by weather, work at home, travel etc. (c) the loneliness of the open spaces?

3. Outline briefly any tales or beliefs you have heard about (a) cold weather (b) snow and blizzard (c) hail (d) drought (e) high wind.

Example: the way to tell if the wind is blowing is to nail a chain to the top of a post; if the links stand out straight horizontally, it's windy; if they begin to snap off, it's good and windy. (What variants of this one have you heard?)
2. What jokes did people tell about (a) gumbo (b) foraging streams or getting caught in unusual situations caused by weather, work at home, travel etc. (c) the loneliness of the open spaces?

3. Outline briefly any tales or beliefs you have heard about (a) cold weather (b) snow and blizzard (c) hail (d) drought (e) high wind.

Example: the way to tell if the limbs stand out straight horizontally; it's the top of a post; if they begin to snap off, it's good and windy. (What variants of this one have you heard?)
4. What stories about climate were in general use in the old days?

5. What do people generally remark about a rainbow? A double rainbow? A mirage? Do you know of any strange happenings generally said to be connected with these?

Rainbow at night - sailors take warning.

Rainbow today - rain tomorrow.

6. What weather signs have generally been taken notice of that you remember?

e.g., "Rain before seven, thunder before eleven;" "Red sky at morning, sailors take warning."

7. What animal behavior was generally considered a weather sign and of what kind of weather? e.g., actions of frogs, crickets, groundhogs, wasps, muskrats.

8. Do you remember hearing stories (possibly Indian legends) about the sun, moon, stars?

What is your belief (or others' belief) about sun dogs, a ring around the moon, position of horns of new moon, a change in the moon, sleeping in moonlight? Shooting stars? Use of North Star as a guide — for what? How? Northern lights? Caused by? If so, what kind?

Rising around noon - change in weather.

Ring around moon - dry day.
4. What stories about climate were in general use in the old days?

5. What do people generally remark about a rainbow? A double rainbow? A strange? Do you know of any strange happenings generally said to be connected with these?

Rainbow at night - sailors all right
Rainbow in morning - sailors take warning.

Rainbow today - rain tomorrow

6. What weather signs were generally taken notice of that you remember?

7. What animal behavior was generally considered a weather sign and of what kind of weather? e.g., actions of frogs, crickets, groundhogs, "gadzooks," muskrats.

8. Do you remember hearing stories (possibly Indian legends) about the sun, moon, stars?

What is your belief (or others' belief) about sun dogs, a ring around the moon, position of horns of new moon, a change in the moon, sleeping in moonlight? Shooting stars? Use of North Star as a guide — for what? Poor? Northern Lights? Caused by? Do they make a noise? If so, what kind?

Bring around morning - clear weather
Bring around evening - rainy weather
9. Do you know any stories or beliefs about heavenly bodies, not listed here?

III. SUPPORTING OURSELVES AFTER SETTLEMENT

10. Have you ever kept an account of the weather, bird migrations, blooming time of trees or plants, etc? Do you know anyone who did so? Are these accounts available now?

Supernatural Beings

11. Tell briefly any stories of ghosts or fairies or strange beings who inhabited your pioneer district. From whom did you hear these stories?

(a) hunt local game

(b) use wild plants or their fruits for food (Examples: prairie potato, prairie turnip, saskatoon, wild rice)

Human Beings

12. Do you know any tales of an individual who once lived where you do (or did live) who performed prodigious or somehow unusual deeds? Or who was notably wise or silly, strong or feeble, well formed or misshapen? Tell briefly. From whom did you hear these?

How were these helpers treated: as servants, as members of the family, somewhere in between?

What was the basis of payment?
9. Do you know any stories or beliefs about heavenly bodies, not listed here?

10. Have you ever kept an account of the weather, bird migrations, blooming time of trees or plants, etc.? Do you know anyone who did so? Are these accounts available now?

II. Tell briefly any stories of ghosts or fairies or strange beings who inhabited your pioneer district. From whom did you hear these stories?

(a) Supernatural Beings

(b) Human Beings

(c) Animals

(d) Plants

(e) Other

12. Do you know any tales of an individual who once lived where you do (or did live) who performed prodigious or somehow unusual deeds? Or who was notably wise or silly, strong or feeble, well formed or misshapen? Tell briefly. From whom did you hear these?
Animals

13. What tales or anecdotes do you remember where animals provided the main action or in which animals as well as people are involved? E.g., buffalo, deer, rabbit, gopher, birds, insects (such as bees, grasshoppers, mosquitoes, fish).

III SUPPORTING ONESELF AFTER SETTLEMENT

14. How did you learn to do the following: (Example: learned from other settlers, Indians, read in book, etc.).

(a) build a house

(b) put in and harvest a crop

From my forefathers & reading

(c) hunt local game

From my father

(d) use wild plants or their fruits for food (Example: prairie potato, prairie turnip, saskatoon, wild rice); list others.

15. Did you have help other than members of your family for (a) outdoor work (b) housework?

seldom

How were these helpers treated: as servants, as members of the family, somewhere in between?

What was the basis of payment?

Whatever was the "going" wages.
Animals

13. What tales or anecdotes do you remember where animals provided the main action or in which animals as well as people are involved? E.g., wolf, fox, bear, rabbit, bird, insect (such as bees, grasshoppers, mosquitoes, fish).

III. SUPPORTING ONSELF AFTER SETTLEMENT

14. How did you learn to do the following? (Examples: Learned from other settlers, family, Indians, read in book, etc.)

(a) build a house

(b) put in and harvest a crop

(c) hunt local game

(d) use wild plants or their fruits for food (Examples: prairie potatoes, prairie turnip, astilbe, wild rice); list others.

15. Did you have help other than members of your family for (a) outdoor work

(b) housework?

How were these helpers treated: as servants, as members of the family, somewhere in between?

What was the basis of payment?

Whatever was the going wage.
16. What domestic animals did you have for work? What were their names?

Horses only

What animals did you have for food?

Cattle, pigs

What pets did you have? What were their names? (Example: dog, cat, canary or other bird, wild animal or bird you tamed?)

Always a dog
My mother often had a canary

IV FAMILY OR GROUP GATHERINGS IN THE PIONEER COMMUNITY

17. Comment on the following activities. Add others wherever possible.

(a) Story telling.

Were the stories about animals, people of another time, ghosts, fairies, Indians? Give brief outlines of stories you remember.

(b) Singing

Did just anybody tell these stories or was there someone with a reputation as a teller of tales who usually did so? Man or woman?

Were the songs story-telling songs (ballads) or were they about an emotion (for example, love songs) or work songs (for example railroad or cowboy)?

Were there some of each?

Were there hymns, or hymn tunes with different words?

Were the songs accompanied by a musical instrument (e.g. mouth organ, fiddle, zither)?
16. What domestic animals did you have for work? What were their names?

What animals did you have for food?

What pets did you have? What were their names? (Examples: dog, cat, cow, or other bird, wild animal, or fish you raised?)

IV. FAMILY OR GROUP GATHERINGS IN THE PIONEER COMMUNITY

17. Comment on the following activities. Add others wherever possible.

(a) Story telling.

Were the stories about animals, people of another time, ghosts, fairies, Indians? Give brief outlines of stories you remember.

(b) Singing.

Were the songs story-telling songs (ballads) or were they about an emotion (for example, love songs) or work songs (for example, railroad or cowboy)?

Were there hymns, or hymn tunes with different words?

Were the songs accompanied by a musical instrument (e.g., mouth organ, fiddle, etc.)?
Put down the first lines of as many songs of the pioneer period as you can remember.

Were any popular songs composed by people in the district? If so set down as many as you can remember.

(c) Swapping stories

Comment on the following and add others if possible:

Anecdotes (about settlers' adventures; Indians; animal behavior; hunting adventures; the party line, etc.).

Jokes (tricks played on people; jokes on pioneering life; showing the funny side of something serious, etc.).
Put down the first three of so many songs of the pioneer period as you can remember.

Here are popular songs composed by people in the district. If you set them down as many as you can remember.

(c) Recounting stories with content

Comment on the following and add others if possible:

1. Indian adventures (about several adventures; Indians; animal behavior; hunting adventures; the party line, etc.)

Jokes (jokes played on people; jokes on pioneering life; stories)

The funny side of something serious, etc.).
Tall tales (exaggerated accounts of some well-known character, who may be local; strange happenings, etc.).

20. At what age were children baptized or christened?

Tongue twisters ("Peter Piper picked --"; "She sells seashells --", etc.). Complete examples, give others.

21. By whom were children baptized or christened?

Riddles ("Thirty white horses upon a red hill --"; "Little Ann Netticoat in a white petticoat --"). Complete examples, give others.

V LIFE CYCLE IN THE PIONEER COMMUNITY

Childhood

18. Complete the verse "Monday's child is fair of face --". Give any others similar to this, where the day of the week or the month of the year of a child's birth is supposed to affect its appearance, character or fate. Do you remember other circumstances of birth that affect one's fate, such as being born during a storm or when the mother is away from home, etc?

25. What finger and toe games were played with babies when you were small?

19. By whom were children baptized or christened?

By the local Lutheran minister

List the Christian names of 10 of your friends, either sex.

Hans, Matt, Pete, George, Barney, Sam,

Hughie, Alex, Joe, Charlie

Which was more customary in your childhood—one name or two?

Two
Tall tales (exaggerated accounts of some well-known character, who may be local) and song interpolations, etc.,).

Tongue twisters ("Peter Piper picked ..."; "The Sally seasheells ...", etc.). Complete examples, give others.

Riddles ("Thirty white horses upon a red hill ..."; "Little Jim Headcoat in a white petticoat ..."). Complete examples, give others.

V LIFE CYCLE IN THE PIONEER COMMUNITY

Childhood

18. Complete the verse "Monday's child is fair of face ...". Give any others similar to this, where the day of the week or the month of the year of a child's birth is supposed to affect its appearance, character or fate. Do you remember other circumstances of birth that affect one's fate, such as being born during a storm or when the mother is away from home, etc?

19. By whom were children baptized or christened?

List the Christian names of 10 of your friends, either sex.

Which was more customary in your childhood—one name or two?
9. Were children generally named "after someone" and if so, was the someone a friend -- a person prominent in the world -- a relative (living or dead)? 

Were children given a name just because one of the parents chose it as being "a nice name" or "a pretty name"? Other reasons?

20. At what age were children baptized or christened? 
   As soon after birth as possible.

Was it considered unlucky or unwise to delay baptizing or christening a child? No.

21. By what name did you call your parents? Mom and Dad? Mother and Father? Mummy and Daddy? Other? Mamma Papa.

22. Were children's birthdays celebrated? How?

23. What prayers were taught you? Complete examples and give others, either bedtime, or grace before meals: "Now I lay me --"; "Matthew, Mark, Luke and John, bless --".

24. What lullabies or cradle songs do you remember? Complete examples, give others: "Rock-a-bye, Baby --"; "Bye-bye-Baby Bunting --".

25. What finger and toe games were played with babies when you were small? 
   Complete examples, give others: "This little pig went to market --"; "Let's go to bed, said Sleepy-head --"; "Thumbiken, thumbiken --".

26. By what alphabet rhymes did you learn your ABC's? Complete example, give others: "A was an Archer --"; "A was an Apple pie --".
Here children generally named "after someone" and if so, was the someone a friend — a person prominent in the world — a relative (living or dead)? William by our family was not named.

Here children given a name just because one of the parents chose it as being "a nice name" or a pretty name? Other reasons?

20. At what age were children baptized or christened? Was it considered unlucky or undue to delay baptizing or christening a child? No

21. By what name did you call your parents? Mom and Dad? Mother and Father? Mummy and Daddy? Other? Name: Nana

22. Were children's birthdays celebrated? How? Adults? How?

23. What prayers were taught you? Complete examples and give others, either bedtime or grace before meals: "Now I Lay me —"; "When I'm sick, Luke and John, bless —".

24. What lullabies or cradle songs do you remember? Complete examples, give others: "Rock-a-bye Baby —"; "Hey-hey-Baby Bunting —".

25. What finger and toe games were played with babies when you were small? Complete examples, give others: "This little pig went to market —"; "Let's go to bed", said sleepy-head —; "Thumbkin, thumbkin, thumbkin —".

26. By what alphabet rhymes did you learn your ABC's? Complete example, give others: "I was an Archer —"; "A was an Apple pie —".
27. Do you remember which nursery tales you liked best? Cinderella? Jack and the Beanstalk? List titles of 5 you remember. As you list them which are those you "haven't thought of in years"? Which are the ones your own children know?

28. Which game songs were part of your play? Complete examples, give others: "I sent a letter to my love ---"; "London Bridge is falling down ---".

29. What counting-out rhymes did you use to determine who was "It"? Complete examples, give others: "Eeny, meeny, miny, mo ---"; "Intra, mintra, cutra, corn ---".

30. What did you believe would happen, when you were a child, if you (a) stepped on a crack (b) did not pick up a pin (c) swallowed a fruit pip?

31. When you lost your baby teeth, what did you do with them? If they disappeared, who was responsible and was anything left for you in their place?

Marriage

32. What accessories were considered indispensable for the bride? Example: white dress -- veil -- ring -- "something old, something new, etc."

33. What connected with a wedding would bring bad luck? (E.g. bride trying on wedding dress, seeing groom morning of wedding).

What would bring good luck? (E.g. shower of rice, old shoes).
27. Do you remember which nursery tales you liked best? Cinderella? Jack and the Beanstalk? List titles of 5 you remember. As you list them, which are those you haven't thought of in years? Which are the ones your own children know?

28. Which game songs were part of your play? Complete examples, give others:

- "Tally ho, tally ho, tally ho, tally ho!"
- "London Bridge is falling down"

29. What counting-out rhymes did you use to determine who was "it"? Complete examples, give others:

- "Ferry, money, money, mo —"
- "Tinny, mirror, mirror, corn —"

30. What did you believe would happen when you were a child, if you (a) stepped on a crack (b) did not pick up a pin (c) swallowed a fruit pit?

31. When you lost your baby teeth, what did you do with them? If they disappeared, who was responsible and was anything left for you in their place?

Marriage

32. What accessories were considered indispensable for the bride? Example: white dress — veil — ring — "something old, something new, etc."

33. What connected with a wedding would bring bad luck? (E.g., bride trying on wedding dress, seeing groom wearing of wedding.)

What would bring good luck? (E.g., shower of rice, old shoes).
Were any jokes played on them after the wedding or at any other time? Give details.

Death

34. What was believed to be a sign someone was going to die? (Example: dog howling, plaster falling from ceiling).

We had no superstitions.

35. How much time elapsed between death and burial?

Two days

Was this interval considered "proper" or merely convenient or prudent?

Convenient

36. Did anyone "sit up with the corpse"? No If so, who and how chosen?

37. Instead, was there a wake? No Always? Sometimes? For certain people and not others? Explain.

Was there food and drink served at a wake? What?

38. Was there any difference of procedure at a child's funeral from that at an adult's funeral?

39. In the absence of a representative of the church, who conducted burial services?

VI GOOD AND BAD LUCK

40. Was there a day in the week when it was said undertakings would prove unlucky or would be otherwise unsuitable (e.g., not threshing on Friday). Why? Give other examples.

My father would never start a project on a Friday. He always paved a wheat sheaf to put upon a pole for a treat for the birds at Christmas. We thought a "singing" kettle meant death. I have no superstitions but for some reason our son is much like his grandfather.

41. Name 5 things that bring good luck (e.g., putting on garment inside out by mistake, horseshoe over door).

Name 5 things that bring bad luck (e.g., a bird in the house; spilling salt).

Walking under a ladder
Black cat crossing the road ahead
Putting shoes on the table
A picture falling from wall means death in the family.

Name 5 ways to avoid bad luck (e.g., touch wood, cross your fingers).
were any jokes played on them after the wedding or at any other time? Give details.

Death

34. What was believed to be a sign someone was going to die? (Examples: dog howling, plaster falling from ceiling).

We had no confirmation.

35. How much time elapsed between death and burial?

Was this interval considered proper or merely convenient or prudent?

Just days.

36. Did anyone "sit up with the corpse"? If so, who and how chosen?

No.

37. Instead, was there a wake? Always? Sometimes? For certain people and not others? Explain.

Was there food and drink served at a wake? What?

38. Was there any difference of procedure at a child's funeral from that at an adult's funeral?

39. In the absence of a representative of the church, who conducted burial services?

VI. GOOD AND BAD LUCK

40. Was there a day in the week when it was said undertakings would prove unlucky or would be otherwise unsuitable (e.g., not the working on Friday)? Why?

My mother would never plant a garden on a Friday.

He always pointed out what should be planted on a Friday.

A tithe in the land at Christmas was the best thing to do.

I have no superstitions but for some reason I don't put anything inside out by mistake, horseshoe over door.

41. Name 5 things that bring good luck (e.g., putting on garment inside out).

Name 5 things that bring bad luck (e.g., a bird in the house; spilling salt). Walking under a ladder.

Black cats crossing the road ahead.

Putting shoes on the table.

A picture falling from wall means death in the family.

Name 5 ways to avoid bad luck (e.g., touch wood, cross your fingers).
42. Describe the use of the following in locating articles or foretelling future events (if not sure, tell what you think is done; add "not sure").

- a ring; a Bible; a divining rod (of what wood? to find what?);
- playing cards; tea leaves; coffee grounds.

43. What would you say was the general attitude in your family towards the things mentioned in questions 40 to 42? (Check the statement below most closely resembling the general attitude):

- "True, but you can't explain it logically".
- "Well, there could be something in it, but --".
- "Ridiculous—just superstition!"

What was the attitude in your district?

Most said they weren't superstitious but "wouldn't take a chance".

44. Is the attitude today different? Can you give a reason for your answer?

Quite different—the superstitions have not been proven down through the years.

VII PROVERBS AND PROVERBIAL PHRASES

45. Complete the following:

"A bird in the hand —"; "As the days begin to lengthen —"; "A task begun —". Set down as many more as you can.

A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.
As the days begin to lengthen, the nights get shorter.
A task begun is half done; Better late than never.
Make hay while the sun shines; Sing before breakfast or before night.

46. Complete the following:

"As fresh as —"; "As smart as —"; "Scarcer than —"; Set down as many more as you can.
42. Describe the use of the following in locating articles or foretelling future events: (If not sure, tell what you think is done) add "not sure" to a ring; a Bible; a divining rod (or what wood? to find what?)

43. What would you say was the general attitude in your family towards the things mentioned in questions 40 to 42? (Check the statement below most closely resembling the general attitude):

- True, but you can't explain it logically.
- Well, there could be something in it, but —.

"Hilarious—just superstition!"

What was the attitude in your district?

44. Is the attitude today different? Can you give a reason for your answer?

Quite different—the superstitions have not been further driven than the years.

All Proverbs and Proverbial Phrases

45. Complete the following:

"A bird in the hand —"; "As the days begin to lengthen —"; "A task begun —"; Set down as many more as you can.

A bird in the hand is worth two in the bush.
As the days begin to lengthen, the nights fall short.
A task begun is easy done. Better late than never.
Make hay while the sun shines. Sow by the harvest before night.

46. Complete the following:

"As fresh as —"; "As smart as —"; "Scarceer than —"; Set down as many more as you can.
Oxford.
